column1: Esophageal spasms are abnormal contractions of the muscles in the esophagus (the tube that carries food from the mouth to the stomach).
Very hot or very cold foods may trigger spasms in some people.
Tests you may need to look for the condition include: - Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) - Esophageal manometry - Esophagogram (barium swallow x-ray)
Long-term (chronic) cases are sometimes treated with low-dose antidepressants such as trazodone or nortriptyline to reduce symptoms.
Rarely, severe cases may need dilation (widening) of the esophagus or surgery. to control symptoms
Call your health care provider if you have symptoms of esophageal spasm that don't go away.
The symptoms may actually be due to heart problems.
